conclusion: Given the magnitude of the electric field at midpoint O is E, use superposition to find the field at point A.
Electric field due to a point charge q at distance r is E = k*q/r^2.
Distance from each charge to point O is L/2, so E1 = 4k*q/L^2.
Charges are opposite, so fields at O are in opposite directions. E = |4k*q/L^2 + 4k*(-q)/L^2| = 4k*q/L^2.
Distance from each charge to point A is L*sqrt(2), so E3 = k*q/(2L^2).
Charges are opposite, so fields at A are in opposite directions. E = |k*q/(2L^2) + k*(-q)/(2L^2)| = k*q/(2L^2).
Magnitude of the electric field at point A is k*q/(2L^2).
